content: The "Protect and Preserve International Cultural Property Act" defines cultural property and identifies the appropriate congressional committees. It also includes findings and a statement of policy. Congress finds that protecting international cultural property is crucial for US cultural diplomacy, demonstrating respect for other cultures and the shared heritage of humanity. Instances of cultural property being lost, damaged, or destroyed due to various threats are highlighted, such as the ransacking of museums in Egypt and the looting of the Iraq Museum after the fall of Saddam Hussein. In Iraq and Syria, cultural heritage sites and artifacts have been looted, damaged, and destroyed due to conflicts and actions by groups like ISIS/ISIL. This includes the loss of thousands of items from the Iraq Museum and the shelling of medieval cities in Syria. In Iraq and Syria, ISIS/ISIL has destroyed cultural sites and artifacts to eradicate minorities. In Mali, Ansar Dine destroyed tombs in Timbuktu, while in Afghanistan, the Taliban destroyed the Bamiyan Buddhas. In Afghanistan, the Taliban destroyed the Bamiyan Buddhas, ancient statues carved into a cliff side, leading to worldwide condemnation. In Cambodia, the Khmer Rouge systematically destroyed Buddhist temples, desecrated statues, and destroyed Buddhist literature. In China, during the Cultural Revolution, many of China's antiques were destroyed, including parts of old Beijing. Chinese authorities are now trying to rebuild some of the lost architectural heritage. In China, during the Cultural Revolution, many antiques were destroyed, including parts of old Beijing. Chinese authorities are now rebuilding lost architectural heritage. In Haiti, the 2010 earthquake destroyed art, artifacts, and archives, and partially destroyed the 17th century city of Jacmel. The 2004 Indian Ocean earthquake and tsunami damaged or destroyed libraries, archives, and UNESCO World Heritage Sites in eleven countries. The destruction of cultural properties like Mahabalipuram in India, Sun Temple of Koranak, and Old Town of Galle in Sri Lanka is a loss for all. The US Armed Forces have played a vital role in preserving cultural property since 1943. President Roosevelt established the American Commission for the Protection of Artistic Monuments in War Areas, forming MFAA teams for this purpose. The Monuments, Fine Arts, and Archives (MFAA) teams, also known as the "Monuments Men," were formed by the American Commission for the Protection of Artistic Monuments in War Areas during World War II. The U.S. Committee of the Blue Shield was established in 2006 to support the Hague Convention for the Protection of Cultural Property and work with the military and other government branches. The U.S. Committee of the Blue Shield was established in 2006 to support the implementation of the 1954 Hague Convention for the Protection of Cultural Property in the Event of Armed Conflict. It aims to coordinate with the United States military and other organizations to preserve international cultural property threatened by various disasters. The policy of the United States is to protect and preserve international cultural property at risk of destruction due to political instability, armed conflict, or natural disasters, in line with its obligations under the Hague Convention. The United States aims to protect international cultural property in conflicts and disasters, prevent importation of pillaged cultural property, and enforce laws to prevent trafficking in stolen cultural property. SEC. 4. WHITE HOUSE COORDINATOR FOR INTERNATIONAL CULTURAL PROPERTY PROTECTION. The President appoints a White House Coordinator for International Cultural Property Protection to coordinate and promote efforts involving multiple federal agencies, submit annual reports to congressional committees, provide policy recommendations, and resolve interagency differences efficiently. The White House Coordinator for International Cultural Property Protection is appointed by the President to coordinate efforts among federal agencies, provide policy recommendations, resolve interagency differences, and collaborate with domestic and international actors to promote and protect cultural property. SEC. 5. INFORMATION ON ACTIVITIES TO PROTECT INTERNATIONAL CULTURAL PROPERTY. The Secretary of State must provide information to the White House Coordinator on efforts to protect international cultural property, including activities related to the Hague Convention during armed conflicts. This includes procedures to safeguard cultural property at risk and actions taken in conflicts involving the United States. The Secretary of State must provide information on efforts to protect international cultural property during conflicts, including actions taken by the Department and other statutes, agreements, or policies. The Administrator of USAID must also report on their efforts to protect international cultural property, including coordination with other agencies and organizations. The White House Coordinator for International Cultural Property Protection oversees USAID's efforts to protect cultural property at risk from various threats. The Department of Defense also reports on its activities to safeguard cultural property in accordance with international agreements and conventions. The Department of Justice implements directives, policies, and regulations to protect international cultural property at risk from destruction. They also take actions to prevent damage to cultural property during construction activities abroad. The Attorney General, in consultation with the Secretary of Homeland Security, submits information on these activities. The Attorney General, in consultation with the Secretary of Homeland Security, provides information on Department of Justice efforts to protect international cultural property, including statutes and regulations used in criminal actions to prevent trafficking in stolen cultural property. The Department of Justice has utilized statutes and regulations in criminal, civil, and civil forfeiture actions to prevent trafficking in stolen cultural property and investigate transnational organized crime. They have also taken actions to ensure consistent and effective application of law in cases involving international cultural property, whether located abroad or attempted to be imported into the United States. Authorization for federal agencies to engage in international cultural property protection activities with the Smithsonian Institution. Federal agencies are authorized to enter agreements with the Smithsonian Institution to engage personnel for international cultural property protection activities. They can pay for salaries and expenses to support these activities, including military or diplomatic efforts. Federal agencies can pay for salaries and expenses of Smithsonian Institution personnel to assist in international cultural property protection activities, including support for military, diplomatic, and law enforcement efforts. The Secretary of State is authorized to make grants for international cultural property protection activities in areas at risk of destruction. Additionally, emergency protection for Syrian cultural property is provided for. The President will apply import restrictions to archaeological and ethnological material of Syria as if Syria were a State Party to the Convention on the Cultural Property Implementation Act. These restrictions will take effect within 60 days of the enactment of this Act. The Act enacts import restrictions on archaeological and ethnological material of Syria, defining the material as cultural property unlawfully removed from Syria after August 18, 2011. The term "State Party" refers to countries defined in the Convention on the Cultural Property Implementation Act.
